titleStmt.title: [University of Chicago Library GMS-0166, a manuscript catalogue description in electronic form]
titleStmt.funder: Institute of Museum and Library Services

publicationStmt.publisher: University of Chicago Library, Special Collections Research Center

overview.p: Trephologion or Festal Menaion in Greek. Contains liturgical texts, canons and hymns for major fixed feasts and important saints. Indications of mode and instructions for repetition are paired with texts. Addition of mid-19th century drawings. Formerly Goodspeed Ms. Grk. 18.

headpieces.p: Headpieces decorated with leaf scrolls or interlace and floral motifs in red or black, and red and black.

initials.p: Major initials (30-45 mm) of looped ribbon design set off from the text. Minor initials set off from the text in red or in purple.

watermarks.p: Watermarks similar to Briquet, Ancre dans un cercle, 514 (Udine, 1536); Fleur, 6683 (Rome, 1545-1550); Lettre M, 8371 (Modène, 1481-1483); Main 10734 (Syracuse, 1529); Tête de bœuf, 14794 (Brescia, 1461).
Owing to the manuscript's rebinding, the watermarks primarily are situated in the fold of the leaves are no longer visible.

foliation.p: 1-332. Modern foliation in Arabic numerals in pencil in lower margin. Earlier numbering in ink (upper outer corner).

collation.p: 43 quires of 8 leaves. Estimate of content lost: 1 to 3 leaves (service for November 13, begins on fol. 2r with the Theotokion preceding the Eisodos); unknown number of leaves (after fol. 19, service for November 13, ends after the Theotokion at the finish of Lauds); 1 leaf (after fol. 43, service for September 14, ends following the Great Doxology in the idiomelon); unknown number of leaves (after fol. 328, service for June 29); unknown number of leaves (after fol. 332, service for July 20).

handDesc.p: Written in minuscule script in black ink.
Punctuation includes full point, comma, colon, colon and dash, and the mark of interrogation. Several instances of quotation marks in the margins.

condition.p: Trimmed presumably during the manuscript's rebinding of the late 19th or early 20th century, thus marring marginal drawings. Insect damage, random holes, and taped repairs. Water and grease stains.

binding.p: Binding of half-cloth and paper over wood dated to the late 19th or early 20th century was removed in 2015. The manuscript was rebound in brown tooled goatskin with a linen lining over oak boards.

origin.p: The manuscript is judged to have been written in either Italy or Greece, and is dated to the 16th century.

provenance.p: Provenance from the 16th to the 19th century is unknown. The manuscript may have belonged to Joannes Adam, who lived in the Greek region of Epirus, and who illustrated 10 of the texts (his colophon, fol. 224r; signature fol. 79v). The priest Brapos, whom Adam noted was his uncle, may also have been a one-time owner.

acquisition.p: Acquired by the University of Chicago in 1930 from bookseller Athenas Grivakis with funds from an anonymous donor.

projectDesc.p: The Edgar J. Goodspeed Manuscript Collection contains 68 Greek, Armenian, Latin, Syriac, Ethiopic, and Arabic manuscripts, which range in date from the fifth to the nineteenth century. With support from the Institute of Museum and Library Services National Leadership Grants for Libraries, Building Digital Resources program, the University of Chicago Library has created the online Goodspeed Manuscript Collection, a unique digital resource with manuscripts digitized in their entirety and presented with high-quality zoomable images through an interface that supports browsing within individual manuscripts and across the collection.

Descriptions of the manuscripts have been encoded using the standard set forth in TEI Consortium, eds., TEI P5 Guidelines for Electronic Text Encoding and Interchange: Manuscript Description, at http://www.tei-c.org/release/doc/tei-p5-doc/en/html/MS.html as of 2012-09-22.

The TEI DTD used was obtained from the Digital Scriptorium of Columbia University at, https://www1.columbia.edu/sec/cu/libraries/bts/digital_scriptorium/technical/ds-xml/description_dtd/index.html on 2012-09-22. To accommodate specific project needs, the DTD was edited and extended with local tags in order to describe the content of miniatures, and the structure of canon tables, headpieces, and initials. The process of editing included equating the element Decoration with the seven recognized elements of the TEI Manuscript Description, not only to emphasize intellectual substance, but also to augment visibility by providing links from the record through encoding to the digitized imagery of the Web display.

keywords.term: Orthodox Eastern Church--Liturgy and ritual. Trephologion

overview.p: Trephologion or Festal Menaion in Greek. Contains liturgical texts, canons and hymns for major fixed feasts and important saints. Indications of mode and instructions for repetition are paired with texts. Addition of mid-19th century drawings. Formerly Goodspeed Ms. Grk. 18.

msItem.summary: November 13: Service (lacking).
September 8: Birth of our most Holy Lady, the Theotokos.
September 14: Elevation of the precious and life-giving Cross (lacking).
October 26: Of the holy megalomartyr Demetrios.
November 8: Synaxis of the bodiless and heavenly orders of Angels.
November 21: Entry of the Holy Theotokos into the Temple in Jerusalem.
December 6: Of the holy father Nicholas, Bishop of Myra.
December 24: Eve of the Nativity of Christ.
December 25: Nativity of our Lord and God and Savior Jesus Christ.
January 1: Circumcision of Our Lord Jesus Christ; Of the holy father Basil the Great.
January 5: Eve of the Theophany.
January 6: Theophany of our Lord, God and Savior Jesus Christ.
January 7: Synaxis of John, the Prophet, Forerunner, and Baptist of the Lord.
February 2: Presentation of Jesus Christ in the Temple of Jerusalem.
March 25: Annunciation of Our Most Holy Lady, the Theotokos.
April 23: Of the holy glorious megalomartyr George.
May 2: Of the holy father Athanasius the Great, bishop of Alexandria.
May 8: Of the holy apostle and evangelist John the Theologian.
June 24: Nativity of John the Baptist.
June 29: Of the holy glorious leaders of the apostles, Peter and Paul (lacking).
msItem.note: Leaves missing after fol. 328. The last four leaves are bound out of order. For correct sequence of text read, fols: 331, 329, 330.

msItem.summary: July 20: Of the holy glorious prophet Elijah (lacking).
msItem.note: The last leaves are bound out of order. For correct sequence of text read, fols: 330, 332.
